text: welcome to Monday's edition of times
cast the latest on US efforts to
extradite Russian arms dealer Viktor
boot mr. boots really free of any
ideology and he's motivated by money a
scientific look at an increasingly
annoying pest people are saying we're
probably going to have to get used to
them and a visit to a Sikh temple where
anyone can come and eat I believe in
this place a lot and I get much peace of
mind when I'm here American and Russian
officials have been in a standoff over
the fate of Victor boot the notorious
Russian arms dealer his extradition to
the United States that face criminal
charges has been ordered but there's
been a lot of Russian diplomatic
pressure on Thailand not to deliver him
to the US the Russians are believed to
be a little afraid about what he might
reveal to American authorities about the
intersection of Russian organized crime
the Russian military and Russian
intelligence agencies he was caught two
years ago in a Drug Enforcement
Administration sting operation in which
he allegedly agreed to supply arms to to
DEA agents who were posing as
representatives of the of Colombia's
FARC guerrilla group mr. boot faces
potentially a life sentence in federal
prison if he's convicted but he might be
able to make a deal he's believed to
have insiders knowledge of the illicit
transport of weapons the illicit
movement of money to terrorist networks
to guerrilla groups to criminal gangs
and he also is believed to have a kind
of inside knowledge of how Russia
operates today so he might well be able
to offer some of that information return
for a lighter sentence mr. boot himself
has denied in a series of interviews and
through his wife Allah that he ever was
an illicit arms trader basically he says
that he's a legitimate businessman who's
been the transport business for years
his wife once said that the reason he
was traveling to South America was not
to make weapons deals with the FARC
guerrilla group but for tango
lesson David Corcoran and Donald McNeil
on the strange resiliency of a quickly
spreading pest Donald McNeil you write
that bed bugs have been around for a
million years why are we writing about
them now because in the last decade
bedbugs have come roaring back why have
they made such a comeback there are
several theories they never completely
disappeared the most likely explanation
is not that the domestic population
research doll though there's a theory
that when we stopped using sprays for
cockroaches and started using Bates
instead which are more effective for
cockroaches that that allow the bedbugs
to research because they don't eat Bates
they want humans but the more likely
explanation because of the genetics of
the bedbugs is they were reintroduced
from overseas contrary to the definition
in my dictionary at least bedbugs don't
spread disease it's a complete mystery
as to why they don't spread disease the
bugs presumably have been biting humans
since humans moved into caves because
they were originally a predator of bats
bats are sources of rabies of Ebola of
SARS of knife of iris of all sorts of
disgusting diseases the federal
government has not really been providing
funds to study bedbugs they're not
actually spreading diseases that make
people sick right bed bugs were largely
gone for 40 years then when they came
back the National Science Foundation was
a little interested because it does pure
science but the National Institutes of
Health not interested because I don't
spread disease but many of the
pesticides that have been used against
them in the past so that might be
partially effective are now banned as
too dangerous so it's kind of a
balancing act we know people are afraid
of bedbugs people are also afraid of
pesticides there's there's no miracle
drug there's no DDT coming down the pike
right now so people are saying we're
probably going to have to get used to
them Lydia polgreen on the seek golden
temple where all are welcome regardless
of religion the golden temple in the
northern Punjab region of India is the
holiest shrine of the Sikh religion
it is a vast complex of marble and
glittering gold is a refuge in a chaotic
country with a history of religious
strife woodland temple is a unique place
in the world which is having a very good
concept the concept of humanity nowhere
is this principle more evident than in
the temples community kitchen that
kitchen is based on the principle to
suppress the caste system in the society
we are human beings and we are equal
that's why everybody sit together eat
together in the kitchen it is perhaps
the largest free eatery in the world on
a weekday 80,000 people dying here on
weekends it's almost twice that each
visitor gets a vegetarian meal served up
by volunteers who come to find a measure
of peace not available anywhere else
Sikhism emerged in the Punjab region in
the 15th century it uses elements of
both Hinduism and Islam while rejecting
the Hindu notion of cast / seeks
everyone is considered equal in all
faiths are welcome at the temple abdomen
man romlin I belong to a Brahmin Hindu
family I get lots of positive vibes from
this place I believe in this place a lot
and I get much peace of mind when I'm
here if we talk about feelings then
whoever comes here feels great they get
a peace of mind they get satisfaction
and whoever will come here will take
something along with them join us again
tomorrow for another edition of times
cast
